Air-Conditioning-Inspection-Report.Executive-Summary: This report should be retained as evidence that the required inspection has been undertaken, and it is recommended that consideration is to be given into implementing the report’s recommendations aimed at reducing energy consumption. Green Zone Surveys (UK) Ltd have been commissioned to undertake an inspection of the air conditioning systems and associated controls at:- Debenhams Plc, Foyleside Shopping Centre, Foyle Street, Londonderry, BT48 6AP on the 29/09/2020 @ 15:55hrs. The Debenhams Store is located within Foyleside Shopping Centre. This four storey retail building is of concrete slab and brick construction built in 1990's. The store trading floors are on all levels with a back of house office area located at level 4. There is a walk way connecting Debenhams to the mall. Lighting within conditioned area provided by compact fluorescent lamps, T8 fluorescent lamps and halogen lamps. The temperature control and ventilation of the sales area is achieved by the use of seven packaged air to air roof-top packaged air handling units which serve the sales area via ducted diffusers. AHU's are as follows; AHU 1 Lower GF, AHU 2 GF Zone A, AHU 3 GF Zone B, AHU 4 2nd floor Zone A, AHU 5 2nd Floor Zone B, Ahu 6 FF Zone A, AHU 7 FF Zone B. At the time of the inspection the units the systems could not be interrogated as they are password controlled. Password was not provided. Each AHU has a has a space temperature sensor associated to it, installed within the conditioned area. There is one heating optimiser installed per floor. This is the controlling point for the AHU's on a particular floor. The optimiser averages the relevant temperature sensors and references them against the outside air temperature. It can then calculate required start times and self learn over a period of time. The optimiser will allow the plant to start, up to 60 minutes before the occupation time configured. The space temperature is monitored out of hours, and if the average temperature drops below 12 Deg C the plant is enabled. The plant will then run for a minimum of one hour, plus a 4 Deg C rise in floor temperature is attained. These optimisers will reside in the master UDC controller (CP1- Unit 1). This will allow one single outstation to control all plant. The BMS will enable the retail AHU's and monitor fault condition only. The AHU's optimisers can be overridden by the "Front of House" override switch located on the managers override panel. Four VRF packaged systems serves staff areas via ducted units / wall mounted units. This system is controlled via a central MITSUBISH G-50A controller located within the roof top plant room. At the time of the inspection the controller was setup top operate the systems on a 7 day timer. Local system controllers located within the conditioned area to allow local control over setpoints, systems can be switched on / off locally. Six single split non inverter systems serve the control room, passenger lift motor room, beauty room x2, goods lift motor room, server room and the kitchen café via wall mounted units, controlled via infrared remote controllers / hardwired remote controllers capable of daily only timer functions. The temperature control and ventilation of the back of house is achieved by the use of a supply and extract MULTIAIR AHU which supplies tempered fresh air via ducted diffusers. System is not capable of heat recovery. All condenser units, air to air roof-top packaged air handling units are located on the buildings flat roof. Core activities within this building is "General Office-125W/sqm" "Server Room-400W/sqm" and "Retai-140W/sqm". The total conditioned area is 6555sqm. The Inspection and report were undertaken in accordance with CIBSE's methodology, Inspection of Air Conditioning Systems TM44: 2012 Edition by an inspector accredited to the National Occupational Standard and accredited by QUIDOS. Sampling guidelines in CIBSE TM44 and the latest agreed CLG Air Conditioning Conventions. - Packaged Systems: 10% of the total number of outdoor units must be inspected (including one of each make), with a minimum of three. An equal number of indoor units must be inspected. - All central chiller plants shall be inspected. For central air handling plant, a minimum of ten units or 30%, whichever number is the greater, shall be inspected. - Terminal units for centralised systems: a 2% sample of the total number of terminal units must be inspected with a minimum of 5 and a maximum of 20. System 1; Single split non inverter system serves the control room via a wall mounted unit (MITSUBISHI, 2003); Model: PUH-P1.6VGAA. Serial number: 3A000124. Cooling capacity: 10kW. Refrigerant charge: 2.50kg (R407C). System 2; Single split non inverter system serves the server room via a wall mounted unit (MITSUBISHI, 2003); Model: PUH-P4YGAA. Serial number: 3A000152. Cooling capacity: 10kW. Refrigerant charge: 2.80kg (R407C). System 3; VRF packaged system serving staff areas via ducted units / wall mounted units. Wall mounted unit serving the cash office was inspected upon (MITSUBISHI, 2003). Supply and extract AHU extracting stale air supplying tempered fresh air (MULTIAIR, est 2003); Model: PUH-P250VMFC. Serial number: Unknown. Cooling capacity: 26kW. Refrigerant charge: 21.10kg (R407C). MULTIAIR AHU: Supply fan motor rating: 6.3kW. Extract fan motor rating: 6.3kW. Supply air volume: 5040m3/h. System 4; Seven packaged air to air roof-top packaged air handling units serve the sales areas via ducted diffusers (EMICON, 2003); (AHU Lower GF) Model: RTP1282CK. Serial number: 02P181. Cooling capacity: 105kW. Refrigerant charge: 60kg (R407C). (AHU 2 GF zone A) Model: RTP1122CK. Serial number: 02P179. Cooling capacity: 82kW. Refrigerant charge: 38kg (R407C). (AHU 3 GF zone B) Model: RTP1122CK. Serial number: 02P176. Cooling capacity: 82kW. Refrigerant charge: 38kg (R407C). (AHU 4 2nd floor zone A) Model: RTP1122CK. Serial number: 02P175. Cooling capacity: 82kW. Refrigerant charge: 38kg (R407C). (AHU 5 2nd floor zone B) Model: RTP1122CK. Serial number: 02P180. Cooling capacity: 82kW. Refrigerant charge: 38kg (R407C). (AHU 6 FF zone A) Model: RTP1122CK. Serial number: 02P177. Cooling capacity: 82kW. Refrigerant charge: 38kg (R407C). (AHU 7 2nd FF zone B) Model: RTP1122CK. Serial number: 02P178. Cooling capacity: 82kW. Refrigerant charge: 38kg (R407C). The total installed cooling capacity of the systems on site is 750.20kW, with a total refrigerant charge of 375.20kg (R410A / R407C). System assessed to be at NOS Level 4. A number of opportunities are outlined within the report that should be considered to maximise efficiency. While there is no mandatory requirement to carry out any recommendations, acting upon the advice within the report may lead to a reduction in energy consumption and operating costs. The primary aim of the Report is to give the building owner, or operator, information about the performance of the system and plant and to identify opportunities to save energy and cut operating costs. This Report identifies any operating anomalies; no-cost/low-cost savings; capital investment opportunities; the size and appropriateness of refrigeration plant in relation to cooling loads and the effectiveness of current maintenance regimes. Included within this report will be a description of the air conditioning services, system efficiencies and approximate sizing of the system compared to industry guidelines and suggested improvements, which could be made to increase the system efficiency. The cooling requirements have been calculated in accordance with industry guidance and should not be treated as an in depth heat load calculation. The Report is based on a visual inspection only. No equipment or plant was removed or stripped down.

ACI-Recommendation.Text: Non inverter system PUH-P4YGAA has EER's of 2.90 which is equal to a C rating.
System PUH-P250VMFC has EER's of 2.90 which is equal to a C rating.
Non inverter system PUH-P1.6VGAA has EER's of 2.80 which is equal to a D rating.
System PURY-P200MF-C has EER's of 2.60 which is equal to a E rating.

The above mentioned systems have poor to average energy efficiency ratings (EER's) using refrigerant R407C. On future replacement ensure that the all split systems are replaced with a highly efficient inverter type using refrigerant R32.
EER's relating to packaged air to air roof-top packaged air handling units could not be confirmed. On future replacement ensure systems are replaced with a highly efficient type.

The client should be aware of the EU HFC (Hydrofluorocarbons) "Phase Down" particularly when considering future installations and system replacements. The client should always opt for systems which contain refrigerants with low GWPs (Global Warming Potential) such as R32 (GWP = 675 kgCO2e). One immediate consequence of the "Phase Down" has been that prices of the refrigerants with high GWPs such as R407C and R410A are already increasing substantially making repairs more costly.
Inspected systems;
Installed systems cooling capacity serving the control room appears to be oversized for it's application, outside a 20% tolerance as recommended by CIBSE.
Installed systems cooling capacity serving the server room appears to be oversized for it's application, outside a 20% tolerance as recommended by CIBSE.
Installed systems cooling capacity serving the cash office room appears to be oversized for it's application, outside a 20% tolerance as recommended by CIBSE.
Installed systems cooling capacity serving the lower ground floor appears to be oversized for it's application, outside a 20% tolerance as recommended by CIBSE.
Installed systems cooling capacity serving the ground floor sales area appears to be correctly sized for it's application, within a 20% tolerance as recommended by CIBSE.
Installed systems cooling capacity serving the first floor sales area appears to be correctly sized for it's application, within a 20% tolerance as recommended by CIBSE.
Installed systems cooling capacity serving the second floor sales area appears to be correctly sized for it's application, within a 20% tolerance as recommended by CIBSE.
On future replacement it is advised that systems are replaced with an inverter type. Inverter systems can modulate power in accordance with demand.
At the end of the installed systems service life, or on future replacement, a detailed cooling load calculation should be carried out instead of replacing with a matching system.

Reduced efficiency results in increased energy use, operating costs and carbon emissions. Energy savings of 2-4% are possible for each degree the condensing temperature is reduced, by efficient and effective operation and maintenance of the air conditioning system and its controls.

The surveyed space has a lighting system with minimal heat gains (compact fluorescent lamps. It is advised that T8 fluorescent lamps and halogen lamps are replaced with a more efficient lighting system with lower heat gains.
It is advised that PIR occupancy sensors are installed to the lighting system within areas of low occupancy.

Inspected terminal unit heat exchangers were seen to be in a clean and undamaged condition. Unit filters were seen to be in a clean condition to displaying light signs of dust (unlikely to affect the systems performance / efficiency).
Rooftop packaged unit heat exchangers and filters were seen to be in a clean and undamaged condition.

External sections of refrigerant pipework's insulation were seen to be in a good condition with insulation intact to a poor condition with small to large areas of damaged insulation resulting in sections of exposed pipework.
Internal sections of refrigerant pipework's insulation were seen to be in a good condition with insulation intact.
One of the most common causes of inefficiencies in an air conditioning systems are dirty components. An 8% decrease in airflow can increase energy consumption by up to 20%.

Be aware that poorly insulated pipe work can affect the efficiency of the air conditioning system. Exposed pipes will act like a heat exchanger and absorb or reject energy before the refrigerant reaches the indoor or outdoor unit reducing the performance of the air conditioning system. Always ensure pipework insulation is of the correct quality and standard as recommended by the manufacture and/or in line with good refrigeration installation practice.
Inspected ductwork sections were seen to be in a good condition with insulation intact.

Ductwork conveying warm air should be insulated to conserve energy. Ductwork conveying cold supply air should be insulated to conserve energy and control condensation at the external surface. Recommendations for the specification and installation of thermal insulation and finishes are given in BS 5422: 1990 and BS 5970: 1992.

Free cooling appears to be utilised. Free cooling is an effective way of reducing the heat load within a building without the need to activate energy hungry compressors. Circulating the cooler external ambient air throughout the building can remove some of the residual heat from the building fabric and can significantly reduce the initial load on the air conditioning systems. With correct control and ductwork configuration savings of 10-15% on site cooling costs could be realised by implementing a free cooling regime.
To optimise air flow ensure all AHU filters are high efficiency (Low energy) "A" rated filters.
Consider introducing Demand Control Ventilation (DCV) to reduce the air flow supplied to the areas during lower occupancy levels.
Consider the savings that could be made by upgrading the current belt driven motors within the AHUs to direct drive speed controlled EC motors.
Consider the savings that could be made to the heating systems by adding the capability of heat recovery to the AHUs.
Maintenance is carried out by Vinci Facilities twice a year plus call outs.

Planned Preventative Maintenance (PPM) documentation including leak check evidence and an f-gas register could not be located at the time of the inspection. Verbally confirmed onsite by the store manager that (PPM) documentation including leak check evidence and an f-gas register are stored centrally at head office. It is advised that PPM documentation including leak check evidence and f-gas register are stored onsite within a building log book.

External sections of refrigerant pipework's insulation were seen to be in a good condition with insulation intact to a poor condition with small to large areas of damaged insulation resulting in sections of exposed pipework. It is advised that refrigerant pipework insulation are repaired / repaired as necessary during routine PPM visits.
Inspected split systems were cooling as expected.
Continue to clean terminal units casing, diffusers, filters, heat exchangers, AHU filters, heat exchangers and condenser unit heat exchangers during routine PPM visits.
The fan belts on the AHU should be inspected by the maintenance contractor and tensioned and/or replaced as necessary.

Air leakage observed from the supply section of the AHU serving the lower ground floor and AHU 5 serving 2nd floor zone B. It is advised that the access doors are repaired to ensure that air leakage does not occur.

There are no differential pressure sensors linked to the AHU's. Consider installing differential pressure sensors to AHU's and link them up to the BMS to allow dusty filters to be more easily identified.
Lower ground floor and ground floor door heaters were not working, fault indicated on HVAC panel. Further investigation required by you maintenance contractor.
VRF system controller functions appear to be sufficient for their application. VRF systems are setup to operate on a 7 day timer.
The York BMS controlling the air to air roof-top packaged air handling units appear to be sufficient for their application. Systems are setup to operate on a 7 day timer.
It is advised that a study is completed on the occupancy profile of the building and it should be ensured that time schedules match the occupancy hours of the building.

On future replacement of the system / controllers it is advised that single split system controllers are upgraded to a more sophisticated type capable of 7 day only timer functions. Consideration should then be given into setting up 'off' only timers on the system controllers so the systems isolate at various times during the day and do not automatically start without manual activation by occupants within the area.
VRF and split systems are not linked to the centralised BMS. Consider linking all split systems the BMS to allow centralised control over all HVAC systems.
During routine PPM visits ensure that the system controllers are programmed to match the correct day / time to ensure any set timers operate correctly.
At the time of the inspection system serving the control room was setup to operate at 16 Deg C within cooling mode.
At the time of the inspection system serving the cash office was setup to operate at 21 Deg C within cooling mode (efficient set point).

At the time of the inspection centralised packaged air to air roof-top packaged air handling units serving the sales area set points range from 19 Deg C to 21.6 Deg C. It is advised that set points are seasonally adjusted.

The following set points will optimise efficiency: The Winter set point should be circa 19°C with the unit set to 'heating' mode. The Summer set point should be circa 24°C operating in 'cooling' mode. In Spring/Autumn the controller should be set to 'auto' mode with a set point range of 21°C - 22°C.

At the time of the inspection systems controller serving the server room could not be located. It is advised that the systems controller is located and replaced and stored within the conditioned area.

Guidance from ASHRAE (American Society Heating Refrigeration and Air Conditioning Engineers) recommends that data centre temperatures can be increased to 27°C depending upon the age of the installed equipment. It is recommended that the server room set-points are increased in small increments of 1°C and if temperature stability proves an issue during peak Summer weather then this can always be reduced for summer. If in doubt the manufacturer of the process equipment should be consulted. However increases in set-points can result in increases in server energy consumption and should be carefully balanced. For example "CIBSE Low Carbon Cooling in Data Centres guide "Key Dale Travel Bursary, 2015" states that, increasing server temperatures from 15°C to 30°C will increase server power by 4 to 8%.
Improving heating / cooling temperature set points by one Degree can bring savings of 8 - 10% of annual heating / cooling consumption.
Split systems have a multiple speed fan selector. To reduce energy consumption consider operating the system in low fan mode.

It is advised that VSD's are installed to AHU fan motors. The client should continually monitor these systems to ensure they are operating correctly. Data should be compiled on each VSD and kept within the building log book to establish if systems are modulating in accordance with demand and aid in identifying periods of excessive consumption.

Changes to control settings should not be made without a thorough investigation into the reason for making the change, the changes may not eliminate the problem, but only mask it and may lead to an increase in energy consumption.

REHVA, the Federation of European Heating, Ventilation and Air Conditioning Associations, has produced interim guidance on the operation and use of building services in areas with a coronavirus disease (Covid-19) outbreak. The general advice is to supply as much outside air as possible into a building. Operators should be aware that virus particles in extract air can re-enter the building. Heat-recovery devices may carry over the virus attached to particles from the exhaust airside to the supply airside via leaks. In rotary heat exchangers (including enthalpy wheels) particles deposit on the return airside of the heat exchanger surface, after which they might be resuspended when the heat exchanger turns to the supply airside. Based on current evidence, REHVA therefore recommends turning off heat recovery sections during SARS-CoV-2 episodes. The full details of the REHVA guidance can be found on the web page https://www.rehva.eu/activities/covid-19-guidance.
Consider placing notices alongside the local system controllers to advise occupants on the method of control for efficient operation of the AC system.
Ensure that the person responsible for operation of the plant on-site is adequately trained in the efficient operation of the AC systems.

The client should be aware of the new F-Gas labelling legislation which came into force on 1st January 2017. By this date it is a legal requirement for all new systems to be clearly labelled with the following information: The type of refrigerant within the system, the weight of the refrigerant in the system, the GWP of the system refrigerant and the total GWP of the system.

The way that we calculate the frequency of mandatory leak checks and threshold values for a system that contains F-Gases has been changed. It is now based on equivalent tonnes of CO2. This may mean that systems under the old F-Gas Regulations that did not need a mandatory leak check may now require one. Also systems that did not need an automatic leakage detection system fitted may now require one. Systems such as : stationary refrigeration equipment, stationary air-conditioning and heat pumps, stationary fire protection equipment and refrigeration units of refrigerated trucks and trailers are examples of systems included in F-Gas Regulations. For systems with less than 3kg charge, the 5 Tonne CO2e threshold applies from 1st January 2017.
For more information, see: www.gov.uk/government/collections/eu-f-gas-regulation-guidance-for-users-producers-and-traders.
This site legally requires to hold a valid f-gas register and undertake annual leak checks for the following systems; PUH-P4YGAA,PURY-P200MFC and PURY-P200MFC.
This site legally requires to hold a valid f-gas register and undertake bi-annual leak checks for the following systems; RTP1122CK and RTP1282CK.

Be aware it is a finable offence if this site does not hold a valid f-gas register / carryout leak checks as required. It is advised that an f-gas register is created and leak checks are carried out as required.
Consider carrying out leak checks on a voluntary basis for systems which are not legally required.
A valid f-gas register must include the following:
- The quantity and type of HFC refrigerants installed in each system;
- Any quantities of refrigerant added;
- The quantity of refrigerant recovered during servicing, maintenance and final disposal;

- Other relevant information including the identification of the company or technician who performed the servicing or maintenance, as well as the dates and results of leakage checks and leakage detection system checks.

Commissioning data relating the EMICON AHU's could not be located. Fan motors did not have rating plates. It is advised that the client locates AHU commissioning data. It is then advised that a specific fan power calculation is carried out to ensure the system complies with the Non-Domestic Building Compliance Guide which requires central balanced mechanical ventilation systems with heating and cooling in existing buildings to have a maximum SFP of 2.2. An additional 0.3 allowable for systems with heat recovery is permitted, i.e. a maximum SFP of 2.5.
If the system does not comply to the above figure ensure remedial action is carried out as required.

SFP rating of MULTIAIR AHU serving BOH area does not comply with the figure stated by the Non-Domestic Building Compliance Guide. It is strongly advised that the client confirms the units commissioning data before any action is taken. If required ensure upgrades are made to the AHU to ensure a maximum SFP of 2.2 is achieved.
Implementing recommendations:
The recommendations are provided as an indication of opportunities that appear to exist to improve the air conditioning systems energy efficiency.
The recommendations are based on best practices from known information at the time of this report.
The recommendations are based on the assessor’s knowledge of the system and its use.
Legal disclaimer:
The advice provided in recommendation reports is intended to be for information only.
Recipients of the recommendation report are advised to seek further detailed professional advice before reaching any decision on how to improve the energy performance of the building.

Filter-Condition-OK.Note: Filter was seen to be in a clean and undamaged condition.

Filter-Change-Frequency-OK.Note: Filters are cleaned twice a year

Differential-Pressure-Gauge-OK.Note: No filter differential pressure gauges are fitted to this unit.

ACI-Recommendation.Text: Consider installing differential pressure gauges to this unit and link them up to the BMS to allow dusty filters to be more easily identified.

Fan-Power-OK.Note:
The current version of the Building Regulations Approved Document Part F and Part L documentation provide guidance on limiting values. This should be adopted as means of comparison to stay inline with current standards.
Commissioning data could not be located. Fan motors did not have rating plates.

ACI-Recommendation.Text:
It is advised that the client locates commissioning data relating to this unit. It is then advised that a specific fan power calculation is carried out to ensure the system complies with the Non-Domestic Building Compliance Guide which requires central balanced mechanical ventilation systems with heating and cooling in existing buildings to have a maximum SFP of 2.2. An additional 0.3 allowable for systems with heat recovery is permitted, i.e. a maximum SFP of 2.5.
If the system does not comply to the above figure ensure remedial action is carried out as required.

Fan-Rotation-OK.Note: The fan rotates correctly with no usual noises / vibrations.

ACI-Recommendation.Text: Consider installing VSD's to AHU fan motors.

Heat-Exchangers-OK.Note: Heat exchangers were seen to be in a clean and undamaged condition.

ACI-Recommendation.Text: Continue to clean and repair heat exchangers as necessary during routine PPM visits.

Refrigeration-Leak.Note: No visual signs of refrigerant leaks.

ACI-Recommendation.Text: Ensure system is leak tested as required.

Consider the savings that could be made by upgrading the current belt driven motors within the AHUs to direct drive speed controlled EC motors.
The fan belts on the AHU should be inspected by the maintenance contractor and tensioned and/or replaced as necessary.

Energy-Conservation-Features.Note: Not capable of heat recovery. Consider the savings that could be made to the heating systems by adding the capability of heat recovery to the AHUs.

ACI-Recommendation.Text: Free cooling is an effective way of reducing the heat load within a building without the need to activate energy hungry compressors. Circulating the cooler external ambient air throughout the building can remove some of the residual heat from the building fabric and can significantly reduce the initial load on the air conditioning systems. With correct control and ductwork configuration savings of 10-15% on site cooling costs could be realised by implementing a free cooling regime.

ACI-Recommendation.Text: Regularly monitor the unit and check that it does not show any visible sign of air leakage and repair any leaks that are present.

Commissioning data located and reviewed.
MULTIAIR AHU: Supply fan motor rating: 6.3kW. Extract fan motor rating: 6.3kW. Supply air volume: 5040m3/h.
5040m3/h = 1400L/S.
6.3kW + 6.3kW * 70% = 8.82kW = 8820W.
SFP = W/L/S. 8820/1400 = 6.3W/L/S.

ACI-Recommendation.Text:
The Non-Domestic Building Compliance Guide requires central balanced mechanical ventilation systems with heating and cooling in existing buildings to have a maximum SFP of 2.2. An additional 0.3 allowable for systems with heat recovery is permitted, i.e. a maximum SFP of 2.5.
It is strongly advised that the client confirms the units commissioning data before any action is taken. If required ensure upgrades are made to the AHU to ensure a maximum SFP of 2.2 is achieved.

Fan-Rotation-OK.Note: The fan rotates correctly with no usual noises / vibrations.

ACI-Recommendation.Text: Consider installing VSD's to AHU fan motors.

ACI-Recommendation.Text: Continue to clean and repair heat exchangers as necessary during routine PPM visits.

Free cooling is an effective way of reducing the heat load within a building without the need to activate energy hungry compressors. Circulating the cooler external ambient air throughout the building can remove some of the residual heat from the building fabric and can significantly reduce the initial load on the air conditioning systems. With correct control and ductwork configuration savings of 10-15% on site cooling costs could be realised by implementing a free cooling regime.

Air-Leakage.Note: No signs of excessive leakage / energy loss observed.

ACI-Recommendation.Text: Regularly monitor the unit and check that it does not show any visible sign of air leakage and repair any leaks that are present.

Outdoor-Air-Inlets.Note: No visible signs of blockages to the inlet grills observed. Unit is not affected by local heat sources and is in good order.

ACI-Recommendation.Text: Regularly monitor the unit and ensure that it does not show any visible signs of blockages to the inlet grills and is not affected by local heat sources.

Filter-Condition-OK.Note: Filter was seen to be in a clean and undamaged condition.

Filter-Change-Frequency-OK.Note: Filters are cleaned twice a year

Differential-Pressure-Gauge-OK.Note: No filter differential pressure gauges are fitted to this unit.

ACI-Recommendation.Text: Consider installing differential pressure gauges to this unit and link them up to the BMS to allow dusty filters to be more easily identified.

Fan-Power-OK.Note:
The current version of the Building Regulations Approved Document Part F and Part L documentation provide guidance on limiting values. This should be adopted as means of comparison to stay inline with current standards.
Commissioning data could not be located. Fan motors did not have rating plates.

ACI-Recommendation.Text:
It is advised that the client locates commissioning data relating to this unit. It is then advised that a specific fan power calculation is carried out to ensure the system complies with the Non-Domestic Building Compliance Guide which requires central balanced mechanical ventilation systems with heating and cooling in existing buildings to have a maximum SFP of 2.2. An additional 0.3 allowable for systems with heat recovery is permitted, i.e. a maximum SFP of 2.5.
If the system does not comply to the above figure ensure remedial action is carried out as required.

ACI-Recommendation.Text: Consider installing VSD's to AHU fan motors.

Refrigeration-Leak.Note: No visual signs of refrigerant leaks.

ACI-Recommendation.Text: Ensure system is leak tested as required.

Consider the savings that could be made by upgrading the current belt driven motors within the AHUs to direct drive speed controlled EC motors.
The fan belts on the AHU should be inspected by the maintenance contractor and tensioned and/or replaced as necessary.

Zoning-Assessment.Note:
Activity: “General Office”.
The surveyed space has a lighting system with high heat gains (T8 fluorescent lamps).

ACI-Recommendation.Text:
Zoning appears to be appropriate.
It is advised that T8 fluorescent lamps are replaced with a more efficient lighting system with lower heat gains.

Indicated day: No function. Indicated time: 16:15hrs. Actual time: 16:57hrs.
If applicable during routine PPM visits ensure that the systems controller is programmed to match the correct day / time to ensure any set timers operate correctly.
Daily only timer functions were not being utilised at the time of the inspection.

Timer-Shortfall.Note: Systems controller is not capable of 7 day timer functions.

ACI-Recommendation.Text: On future replacement it is advised that consideration is given into upgrading the systems controller to a more sophisticated type capable of 7 day only timer functions. Consideration should then be given into setting up 'off' only timers on the system controllers so the systems isolate at various times during the day and do not automatically start without manual activation by occupants within the area.

Sensors-Appropriate.Note: Sensor located within the return air.

ACI-Recommendation.Text: Location and type, adequate.

At the time of the inspection the system was setup to operate at 16 Deg C within cooling mode.
The following set points will optimise efficiency: The Winter set point should be circa 19°C with the unit set to 'heating' mode. The Summer set point should be circa 24°C operating in 'cooling' mode. In Spring/Autumn the controller should be set to 'auto' mode with a set point range of 21°C - 22°C.
Consider placing notices alongside the local system controller to advise occupants on the method of control for efficient operation of the AC system.
If possible consider setting the remote control to 'Automatic' mode, setting a "dead band" of 2 - 3 Degrees C above & below a set point of 21 Degrees C.
Refer to "Advice and comments on control of AC sub system(s)" for further details.
System has a three speed fan motor. To reduce energy consumption consider operating the system in low fan mode.

Zoning-Assessment.Note:
Activity: “Retail”.
The surveyed space has a lighting system with high heat gains (compact fluorescent lamps and halogen lamps).
This system is controlled via a York trend system located within the roof top plant room. Each unit has a built in controller.

ACI-Recommendation.Text:
Zoning appears to be appropriate.
It is advised that halogen lamps are replaced with a more efficient lighting system with lower heat gains.
During routine PPM visits ensure that the systems controller is programmed to match the correct day / time to ensure any set timers operate correctly.

7 day timer functions are being utilised. It is advised that a study is completed on the occupancy profile of the building and it should be ensured that time schedules match the occupancy hours of the building.

Timer-Shortfall.Note: Systems controller capabilities are sufficient for its application. .

ACI-Recommendation.Text: No recommendations

Sensors-Appropriate.Note: There is one heating optimiser installed per floor. This is the controlling point for the AHU's on a particular floor. The optimiser averages the relevant wall mounted temperature sensors and references them against the outside air temperature. It can then calculate required start times and self learn over a period of time. The optimiser will allow the plant to start, up to 60 minutes before the occupation time configured.

ACI-Recommendation.Text: Location and type appears to be appropriate. Ensure outside temperature sensors are accurate and calibrated on a regular basis.

System set points range from 19 Deg C to 21.6 Deg C. It is advised that set points are seasonally adjusted.
The following set points will optimise efficiency: The Winter set point should be circa 19°C with the unit set to 'heating' mode. The Summer set point should be circa 24°C operating in 'cooling' mode. In Spring/Autumn the controller should be set to 'auto' mode with a set point range of 21°C - 22°C.
Ensure that the person responsible for operation of the plant on-site is adequately trained in the efficient operation of the AC systems.
If possible consider setting the remote control to 'Automatic' mode, setting a "dead band" of 2 - 3 Degrees C above & below a set point of 21 Degrees C.
Refer to "Advice and comments on control of AC sub system(s)" for further details.
Consider installing VSD's to fan motors. To reduce energy consumption consider operating the system in low fan mode.

At the time of the inspection the systems controller could not be located.
Guidance from ASHRAE (American Society Heating Refrigeration and Air Conditioning Engineers) recommends that data centre temperatures can be increased to 27°C depending upon the age of the installed equipment. It is recommended that the server room set-points are increased in small increments of 1°C and if temperature stability proves an issue during peak Summer weather then this can always be reduced for summer. If in doubt the manufacturer of the process equipment should be consulted. However increases in set-points can result in increases in server energy consumption and should be carefully balanced. For example "CIBSE Low Carbon Cooling in Data Centres guide "Key Dale Travel Bursary, 2015" states that, increasing server temperatures from 15°C to 30°C will increase server power by 4 to 8%.
Consider placing notices alongside the local system controller to advise occupants on the method of control for efficient operation of the AC system.
